content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the GitHub Skill section and how many courses are under the 'First day on GitHub' heading.  Please interact with https://github.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The task requires locating the "GitHub Skill section" and counting courses under the "First day on GitHub" heading. Typically, skill or learning resources would be found under the "Resources" menu. I should explore the "Resources" dropdown/menu to search for relevant sections.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown under "Resources" now shows "Learning Pathways," which logically could include courses and skill sections. To locate the GitHub Skill section and count courses under "First day on GitHub," I should click on "Learning Pathways."
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page, which may contain the GitHub Skill section and courses. To find the relevant sections such as "First day on GitHub," I should scroll down to view more content on the page.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I see the "Pick your pathway" section with visual cards, but the cookie notification at the bottom may be obstructing view or functionality of the lower part of the content. To ensure easier access while scrolling further, I should accept the cookie notification.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The cookie notification is gone, allowing a full view of the "Pick your pathway" section. However, I don't yet see the "GitHub Skill section" or the "First day on GitHub" heading. I need to scroll further down to try to find the relevant content.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The bottom of the "Pick your pathway" section is visible, but there is no sign yet of the "GitHub Skill section" or the "First day on GitHub" heading. The next section, "Featuring expert insights from," appears just below. I should scroll further down to look for the required sections and headings.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Featuring expert insights from:" section with testimonial cards is visible, but still no sign of the "GitHub Skill section" or the "First day on GitHub" heading. I need to continue scrolling down to search for the required section.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: More testimonial cards and company logos are shown, but there is still no sign of the "GitHub Skill section" or the "First day on GitHub" heading. I need to keep scrolling down to look for the required section.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section titled "GitHub Learning Pathways" is now visible, which likely leads toward the GitHub Skill section and tutorial content. However, the "First day on GitHub" heading or specific courses are still not shown. I should scroll further down to reveal more of the Learning Pathways section.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section "Optimize your GitHub use through expert insight" is visible, suggesting that the relevant tutorials or pathways are coming up. The "First day on GitHub" heading or course list is still not visible. I should continue scrolling to look for the specific heading and courses.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the bottom of the page, seeing the footer section and the "Start your learning pathway" button. The "GitHub Skill section" and "First day on GitHub" heading with courses are not present on this page, suggesting they could be behind the "Start your learning pathway" button or within another section. I should click the "Start your learning pathway" button to explore further.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screen now shows a "Pick your pathway" section with several learning pathways such as "AI-powered development with GitHub Copilot," "CI/CD with GitHub Actions," "Shift left with GitHub Advanced Security," and "Administration and Governance with GitHub Enterprise." There is still no sign of the "First day on GitHub" heading or a clear "GitHub Skill section." I should scroll down further because the needed section likely appears below these featured pathways.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page shows links to explore specific GitHub learning pathways for Copilot, automation, security, and administration. Below, the "Featuring expert insights from:" section begins. There is still no clear sign of a "GitHub Skill section" or a "First day on GitHub" heading, so I should continue scrolling down to look for these elements.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.87
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current view displays testimonial cards about GitHub Copilot and Advanced Security, but there is still no indication of the "GitHub Skill section" or the "First day on GitHub" heading or courses. I should continue scrolling to look for the required information further down the page.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.88
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page currently displays more testimonial cards and then a section showing company logos. The "GitHub Skill section" and "First day on GitHub" heading are still not visible. I should continue scrolling down to check if these sections appear further below.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.89
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "GitHub Learning Pathways" section has appeared, described as self-paced tutorials for various developer needs. This area likely leads to the GitHub Skill section and the "First day on GitHub" heading. To see if the specific courses or headings are listed below, I should scroll further down.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section "Optimize your GitHub use through expert insight" is visible, and the "Start your learning pathway" button could potentially lead to a list of courses and the "First day on GitHub" section. Since scrolling alone hasn't revealed these, I should click the button to access the next step in the learning pathway.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.93

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "Resources", "GitHub resources homepage";	[2]: <button> "Why GitHub", "Show the Why GitHub dropdown menu";	[3]: <button> "Topics", "Show the Topics dropdown menu";	[4]: <button> "Learn", "Show the Learn dropdown menu";	[5]: <button> "Events & Webinars", "Show the Events & Webinars dropdown menu";	[6]: "Enterprise trial";	[7]: "Contact Sales";
